section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate
section-block.rac_book_summary: This book follows a garbage truck’s journey from picking up garbage at the curb and dropping it off at the landfill. Keep your eyes open for lots of different shapes as you Follow That Garbage!

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice counting to 30. Then use Pattern Blocks to review flat shapes. Help children name the shapes they’ve learned and discuss their features, including sides and points.
Hold up different shapes while you sing a song to the tune of “The Muffin Man”: Do you know what shape this is... I’m holding in my hand? The shape is a [shape name].

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Follow That Garbage! by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate.
Lala is going to love reading this informational text. She’ll also see a lot of shapes while reading.
Think about this question as we read, and we’ll talk about it after: Where does garbage go?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Geometry: Ask children to come to the book and look for and point to shapes on the pages.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where do you think garbage goes once it is picked up? I think this book is going to tell us!
I see shapes on the bottom of the truck! What shapes do you see?
The bags of trash are smashed together. Garbage and trash mean the same thing. Why does the trash get smashed?
That’s a lot of trash! The garbage comes from all kinds of buildings, like schools and houses, and goes into the truck. What shapes do you see in this picture?
Why does the soda can say it’s not trash? What does it mean to recycle?
The trash gets pushed into a compactor, which squishes it. The squished garbage goes in an even bigger truck! What shape are this truck’s wheels? Are they the same?
Some trash gets heated up and then broken into rocks. The rocks turn into roads.
Let’s talk about the guiding question: Where does garbage go?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The garbage goes into a garbage truck.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about what happens to garbage as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The garbage goes into a tr____ (truck).
The garbage goes into a truck.
Why is it important to recycle garbage when we can?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning about shapes is the first way children begin to explore geometry. Young children observe that shapes can be combined and broken down to make new shapes (for example, two squares combine to become a rectangle). This helps them begin to see the relationship between two- and three-dimensional shapes.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Follow Classroom Rules

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Every community, including the classroom, has rules and routines that need to be followed. The rules help everyone feel responsible for what they do as part of the group. Children and adults feel more comfortable when they understand what is expected of them. It helps the community thrive!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of Follow That Garbage! by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate.
Clifford loves being a part of our class community. In our class, we have rules and routines. Who can tell Clifford about some of the rules in our classroom?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Focus on Geometry: Challenge children to point to shapes and count them as you read.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The garbage truck follows a routine: it comes every week. How does this routine help the community? (MB)
The people who drive garbage trucks are part of our community. How do they help our community? (MB)
The people who drive garbage trucks follow the same routine. What is the routine they follow? (MB)
There are rules about what is garbage and goes to the landfill and what is not. How do these rules help the community? (MB)
What is a landfill? What shapes do you see on these pages?
We can make soil from trash, which is called compost. What might happen if you don’t follow these steps when trying to compost?

section.rac_body-text: Point out the list of websites on page 24 that can help children learn more about garbage and recycling.

Share any class rules for computer and Internet use, and emphasize that these rules keep everyone safe. Follow these rules to visit a few garbage- or recycling-related websites as a class. Show videos of a garbage truck’s journey if possible.
If Internet access is not available, share additional reading materials instead.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about why it is important to follow classroom rules.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers are usually eager to follow daily routines. Most young children appreciate the structure of classroom rules because predictable rules and routines let them know what to expect throughout the day. Because they are so reliant on routines, children sometimes get frustrated or angry when an adult deviates from the routine. (Miller, Scholastic.com)

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children real examples of solid shapes, including cones, cans, balls, and boxes. Point out the number of sides and that the sides are made of flat shapes.
Point out solid shapes as parts of items in the classroom, such as the cone at the tip of a crayon or a cube as a base for a toy. Ask children what solid shapes they see.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Follow That Garbage! by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate.
Lala loves reading books about real information.
As we read today, think about this guiding question: What happens to the garbage after it gets picked up?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Garbage gets picked up and put in the truck. What solid shapes do garbage cans look like?
Let’s find the shapes on this page. Who can point to a can? Who can point to a circle?
What is the same about a can and a circle? What is different?
The garbage truck has reached the landfill! What happens there?
Now we can see what happens at the landfill at the end of the day.
What shapes do you see on these pages? What real, solid-shaped items could be in the landfill?
Look at the huge piles of trash. What happens to the trash in a landfill?
This page tells us how to compost, or recycle, fruits and vegetables so they don’t end up in the landfill. What rules are there? Why is this a good idea? (MB)
Did you think about the question when we read today?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens to the garbage after it gets picked up?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The garbage is covered with dirt in a landfill.
The garbage gets piled on top of other garbage.
The garbage is heated up and turned into other things.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what happens to garbage after it arrives at the landfill.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What happens to garbage at the landfill?
Garbage at the landfill is covered with d_____ (dirt).
Garbage at the landfill is covered with dirt.
Why is it good that some trash can be turned into rocks?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Clay can be a helpful way to teach three-dimensional shapes to children who may have trouble understanding that flat two-dimensional shapes make up the sides of three-dimensional shapes. Children can use shape cookie cutters to make flat shapes and then join them together to create three-dimensional shapes, like a box or can.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about simple environmentally friendly actions that children can do at home and in the classroom, like turning off the lights when leaving the room or turning off the faucet when they brush their teeth. Incorporating these actions into their daily routines helps these environmentally friendly actions become a permanent part of their lives.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read You Can Help! It is an informational poster full of ways we can help protect the Earth. Why do you think we need to protect the Earth?
Follow That Garbage! and You Can Help! both tell about ways we can protect the Earth. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
How can we care for our world?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Protecting the Earth
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This poster tells us ways we can help protect the Earth. Earth is a planet that holds all the people everywhere in the world. We live on the Earth. We all need to follow rules to protect it! (MB)
We should always remember to turn off the lights when we are the last ones to leave a room. We can make it a routine. (MB)
Let’s look closely at the light switch. Is it a rectangle or circle?
What shape is the Earth? When we look at the picture of Earth we can see all the blue on it. That’s water! Why is water so important?
The recycling symbol looks almost like a triangle. How is it different? This symbol helps us know what or where to recycle.
Do you remember those big piles of garbage in the landfill in Follow That Garbage!? Why is it important to recycle when we can?

section.rac_body-text: Give children drawing materials and paper, and ask them to draw a picture or make a poster explaining one of the ways they can help protect the Earth, such as recycling or turning off the lights. Have children share their drawings with the rest of the class, and then hang them up around school. Alternately, send the drawings home and encourage children to teach their families how to protect the Earth.
Provide a writing prompt about one way children can help protect the Earth and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: If children learn to appreciate the Earth at a young age, they are more likely to work to protect it in the future. Young children begin learning empathy for the people around them during preschool. By teaching them about protecting the Earth, they can learn to extend their empathy to animals, plants, and the environment.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about how methods mentioned in the book, like using trash as landfill and composting, can help make things grow. Discuss how plants need dirt to grow.
Point out that the word recycling has recycle in it. Ask children what other words they hear in the book that have simpler words inside of them.
Play a guessing game with children in which you describe a flat or solid shape and children guess what it is. For example, I am round like a circle, but I can roll. What am I?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Follow That Garbage! by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate.
Lala loves all kinds of books. Who can tell me if this is a book that teaches us information or tells us a made-up story?
We have read all about where garbage goes after we throw it out. When we read today, I want you to think about this question: How can we make less garbage?
Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we will act out parts of the book.
Let’s pretend to work on the garbage truck. We can throw trash into the truck.
What could we do with a box that is still good? How could we use it for something else?
Let’s pretend to drop trash into one of these garbage cans. What can we do with our recycling?
Should we throw away the milk jug and pop can? Why not? Let’s pretend to be the jug and can, and say “no, no, no” to the person trying to throw us in the garbage.
Let’s look for shapes on these pages again. What do you see? Let’s point out the shapes.
Let’s pretend to break up the trash into small rocks.
Let’s act out using a shovel to turn the compost pile like it says to do in step 5. Now all the leftover food can turn into soil to grow new food!
Did you think about the guiding question as we read?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we make less garbage?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can turn food into compost.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about a way they can help protect the Earth.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What could we do with cans instead of throwing them away?
How does making less garbage help the Earth?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Having consistent routines in the classroom can help multilingual learners improve their language skills. If children know which activities take place in each area of the classroom, they can begin to use physical and visual cues to know what to do and how to behave in that area each day.
